body: We should update the `.build/README.md` as we've removed `dtest-offheap` and added `dtest-latest`. It's worth mentioning `build-jars.sh` as well.

> We should update the .build/README.md as we've removed dtest-offheap and added dtest-latest.

Doing this.

> It's worth mentioning build-jars.sh as well.

Not doing this (it doesn't add value, it's only used by CI to create the stash)

>> We should update the .build/README.md as we've removed dtest-offheap and added dtest-latest.
>
>Doing this.

pushed, check new commits.

@michaelsembwever, If you recall I submitted a pull request for Cassandra-12937 that included a change to the `topology.properties` file.  You asked why that change was made and I could not answer as I received it from a development branch that I did not work on.  However, I discovered that if you run `ant test` that file would be overwritten.  While this is not a problem on the CI system it does cause a problem on development systems where the modified file can be accidentally checked in :raised_hand_with_fingers_splayed:.  This change to one file solves the problem.  Please review and let's see if we can get this in.

I can confirm that the problem is reproducible without the changes, and is fixed with the changes.

The command to reproduce:
`ant test` (the scope of the files must be narrowed in advance)

However, the command below doesn't reproduce the issue: 
`ant testclasslist -Dtest.classlistfile=testnameslist.txt`

> However, doing this led to an issue where System tables should not have the default table compression applied. In order to support this the TableParams.builder needs to know the keyspace name when building so that it can be passed to the CompressonParams.builder where the filter for determining which tables get the old DEFAULT and which get the new calculated default Compression params is handled by the CompressionParams.defaultParams(keyspace) method.

> This change in turn led to changes to several files where the keyspace name needed to be provided for the TableParams.builder().build() function call.

Actually why do we need all of those changes? System tables are not something which magically appear in the system - they are created explicitly and we can explicitly set compression to none when creating them?
In HintsReaderTest and HintsDescriptorTest there is code to generate corrupt hints files and then you could test that. Iiuc your patch doesn't test that it catches corrupt files?
@bereng ah thanks, making corrupted hints files is definitely useful

@bereng I choose different approach, it is not so easy to mark some hints descriptor corrupted because it happens asynchronously in `HintsDispatchExecutor.DispatchHintsTask`. I just marked one of descriptors as corrupted calling respective `markCorrupted` method in `HintsStore`.

Hi @bschoening,

Here are some of the observations:
Initially when there is no Capture.
shunted_query_out is `None`
query_out is `<_io.TextIOWrapper name='<stdout>' mode='w' encoding='utf-8'>` which is stdout.

When we start Capturing (example `Capture 'demo_capture.txt'`):
shunted_query_out is `<_io.TextIOWrapper name='<stdout>' mode='w' encoding='utf-8'>` which is stdout
query_out is `<_io.TextIOWrapper name='demo_capture.txt' mode='a' encoding='UTF-8'>` which is the file demo_capture.txt.

According to the observations 
We are not able to get the file information from shunted_query_out. I feel we need to send query_out to shell.writeresults() .
In Tracing.py the  shell.print_formatted_result should be`shell.print_formatted_result(formatted_names, formatted_values, with_header=True, tty=shell.tty, out=shell.shunted_query_out)` in case `out` is None then output should be `query_out`.

Still figuring it out. Open for suggestions.
Contributions need a Jira ticket attached (even small patches). [Link](https://cassandra.apache.org/_/development/patches.html) to the contributing docs.
@Claudenw what exact parameters do you mean? `chunk_length` ?

Updated the PR desc with after. This seems rather significant...

On a quick look, the last few commits make sense, just missing @maedhroz's suggestion from Slack - https://the-asf.slack.com/archives/C018YGVCHMZ/p1717430564268499
I looked around the [CI run](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/blerer/cassandra/413/workflows/fdcfda35-d2f9-4d15-8c76-f6b381b09991), and indeed, the Java test failures are the only suspicious ones; I did not find any tickets.
They may be flaky, `MultiNodeSAITest` is a mighty fuzz test. I hope the seed with which it failed in CI is available in the logs. Also, we need `for i in {1..9}; do sudo ifconfig lo0 alias 127.0.0.$i up; done;`  to be able to run it locally. It is similar to the Python tests but undocumented, and I keep forgetting that detail.

I will make a full pass of the whole work when the latest changes land.
@ekaterinadimitrova2 If `MultiNodeSAITest` isn't something trivial, or the problem reproduces w/ that seed on trunk, definitely let me know...

I will proofread the whole final patch, but at the moment, it seems we are ready.

@Mmuzaf btw, the title here mentions airline-2, but we're actually going to `picocli`, right?
I think this should say simply Python 3 and not mention a specific Python release.  The current Python driver supports Python 3.8 - 3.12.
I have updated the documentation to state that `cqlsh` is compatible with Python 3, as requested. Please review the changes.

It looks like this was just a problem with the 4.1 docs, and that trunk had already been fixed.  I think the current (trunk) section on compatibility is fine as-is, having already removed 2.7, and it's not likely worth fixing it on the 4.1 branch of the docs.

I'd therefore suggest we close this PR and Jira as won't fix.

Thank you for the review and feedback.

I understand that the trunk branch has already addressed the Python 2.7 references, and updating the 4.1 branch documentation isn't necessary at this point.

I will close this PR and the associated Jira issue as "won't fix." 

Thanks again for the guidance.
@dcapwell Thank you for your review comment! I added three tests for the table validation introduced in this patch and modified the existing tests affected.

hi @kenjords I have been very busy in recent months, so I have not pushed forward with this work. I believe that I will have time to continue this work next week. In addition, this work should be nearing completion.

Hi @bschoening , Here are the changes I have made. When code is able to redirect the results to file and traces to stdout (i.e shell). But the color is not preserved. As you can see, the below image is the output of Trace without Capture The below image is the output of Trace during capture. Open to suggestions. Thank you.
+1, LTGM. The only question is whether or not it is worth to check other spots where we are waiting uninterruptibly, in places such as `PaxosBackedProcessor` and `PeerLogFetcher`, etc?

> +1, LTGM. The only question is whether or not it is worth to check other spots where we are waiting uninterruptibly, in places such as `PaxosBackedProcessor` and `PeerLogFetcher`, etc?

I think the instances in `PaxosBackedProcessor` are ok as they already specify timeouts. I don't think there are any uninterruptible waits in `PeerLogFetcher`, but there were a couple in `RemoteProcessor` which I've made interruptible. These were already wrapped by catches for `InterruptedException` so that seems reasonable to me. I've attached a new CI summary to the jira, which again shows no new failures.
